author: David Morton
title: The 132nd Durham Miners' Gala: A short history in 15 historical facts
text:
The 132nd Durham Miners' Gala: A short history in 15 historical facts 13:30, 7 Jul 2016 Tens of thousands will flock to Durham for the annual miners' gala which first took place back in 1871 Shares Get daily news by email Durham Miners' Gala - Thousands in the streets, 1960s 
Durham Miners’ Gala returns for the 132nd time on Saturday. 
Amidst the turmoil of Brexit Britain - with both the Conservatives and Labour in disarray - the gala remains an annual constant in swirling political seas. 
A long-time symbol of working class solidarity - which continues to thrive in this post-coal mining, post-industrial age - we recall the Durham Miners’ Gala in 15 facts: Durham Miners Gala - boy on a drum, 1951 (Beamish Museum) 
The Durham gala, or ‘Big Meeting,’ developed out of the first miners’ union being established in 1869. 
The Durham Miners’ Association organised the inaugural event, which was held in 1871 in Wharton Park, Durham. 
The gala switched to the racecourse site, which has remained its home ever since, the following year. 
The very first meeting was called to celebrate the fact that united action by the miners had broken the grip of unscrupulous coal owners, marking the end of bonded labour. 
At its height, crowds of around 500,000 would gather for the yearly occasion. Today, tens of thousands of people still flock to the gala every year. Mirrorpix Durham Miners Gala - Harold Wilson meets members of the Brandon Women's Institute, 1960s 
In 1925, Bishop of Durham, Hensley Henson, was said to be thrown into the River Wear during the Big Meeting because of his comments that their strikes were immoral as they struggled to avoid starvation on their meagre wages. The tale, however, is probably apocryphal! 
The gala usually begins in Durham city centre with a parade of colliery banners and performances from local brass bands marching across Elvet Bridge. 
The parade ends on Durham University Racecourse at Green Lane with guest speakers, a fairground and entertainment. 
The only time galas haven’t been staged were during the two World Wars, and when major strikes took place in the 1920s and 1980s. Mirrorpix Durham Miners' Gala - Michael Foot, Tony Benn and Neil Kinnock, 1980 
Following the miners’ strike of 1984-1985 and the resulting pit closure programme which decimated National Union of Mineworkers membership, the gala’s future was in doubt. 
Things got so desperate in the mid-1990s it looked like the event might be scrapped. Then New Zealand entrepreneur Michael Watt decided to sponsor it and it was saved. 
Always a colourful occasion, in 2009, for example, 70 or more miners ’ banners, a host of standards from other trade unions and around 60 bands took part in the parade. 
Shunned by both Labour Prime Ministers Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, the Durham Miners’ Gala in 2012 welcomed Ed Miliband, the first Labour leader to attend the gala in 23 years. Durham Miners' Gala - Prime Minister Clement Attlee at the gala, 1951 
Last year saw all four candidates for the Labour Party leadership - including eventual winner Jeremy Corbyn - attending. Mr Corbyn will be a guest at the gala on Saturday. 
Last year’s event attracted an estimated 150,000 visitors and organisers hope even more will attend on Saturday. Durham Miners' Gala 2016
